case_name: State of Bihar v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 236 of 1954 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated October 9, 1953, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 181 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 236 of 1954. Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 9,1953, of the Patna-High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 181 of 1953.

facts.text: The Baidyanath temple is situated in the town of Deoghar within the limits of Santal Parganas in the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: It relates to a temple companymonly known as the Baidyanath temple situate in the town of Deoghar within the limits of Santal Parganas in the State of Bihar.

facts.text: The history of the Baidyanath temple goes back to remote antiquity and is not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this appeal it will be necessary to refer to some earlier litigation about this temple. The history of this temple, it is number disputed, goes back to remote antiquity.

facts.text: The temple shelters a lingam dedicated to Mahadeva and stands in a stone-paved quadrangular courtyard containing eleven other temples.

anchor.surface_text: The temple sheltering the lingam and dedicated to Mahadeva stands in a stone-paved quadrangular companyrtyard. The companyrtyard companytains eleven other temples, smaller in size and of less importance than that of Baidyanath.

facts.text: There is a high priest known as Sardar Panda who used to pay a fixed rent to the Rajas of Birbhum during the Muhammadan regime.

anchor.surface_text: There is a high or chief priest  Sardar Panda  who it appears used to pay a fixed rent to the Rajas of Birbhum during the Muhammadan regime, and the administration of the temple was then left entirely in the hands of the high priest.

facts.text: In 1787, an establishment of priests, collectors and watchmen was organised at Government expense for the management of the temple.

anchor.surface_text: When the British rule began, it was decided to take over the management of the temple, and with this object an establishment of priests, companylectors and watchmen was organised in 1787 at Government expense.

facts.text: In 1791, Government relinquished its claim to offerings and entrusted management to head priest Ram Dutt, ancestor of the respondent, via an agreement.

anchor.surface_text: In 1791 Government relinquished its claim to a share of the offerings and entrusted the management of the temple to the head priest on his executing an agreement to keep the temples in repair and to perform all the usual ceremonies. This agreement was entered into by Ram Dutt  the ancestor of the present respondent , then high priest of the temple and Mr, Keating who was then Collector of the district.

facts.text: Suit No. 18 of 1897 was filed under s. 539 (now s. 92) CPC in the Court of District Judge of Burdwan and decided on July 4, 1901.

anchor.surface_text: There were, however, frequent disputes between the high priest and the pandas regarding the companytrol of the temple and in 1897 a suit was filed under s. 539  number s. 92  of the Code of Civil Procedure in the Court of the District Judge of Burdwan. This was Suit No. 18 of 1897 which was decided by the learned Additional District Judge of Burdwan by his judgment dated July 4, 1901.

facts.text: In Suit No. 18 of 1897, Sailajanund Ojha was dismissed as Sardar Panda and a scheme was framed for temple management.

anchor.surface_text: Sailajanund Ojha was dismissed by the order of the companyrt, as he by his companyduct and behavior and by causing loss to the Debutter properties rendered himself unfit and disqualified to hold the post of Sardar Panda and trustee of the temple of Baidyanath. It was further ordered-by the learned Additional District Judge in the decree granted by him that some fit person be elected as Sardar Panda by the pandas of the temple and that the affairs of the temple be managed under a scheme which was framed by the learned Additional District Judge and formed a part of the decree.

facts.text: Bhabapritananda Ojha, the respondent, was appointed Sardar Panda after the death of Umeshanund Dutt Jha.

anchor.surface_text: After this Umesbanund Dutt Jha, second son of Iswaranund Ojha, was elected Sardar Panda. On the death of Umeshanund Dutt Jha, Bhabapritananda Ojha, who was the petitioner in the High Court and is number respondent before us, was appointed Sardar Panda.

facts.text: The scheme from Suit No. 18 of 1897 was confirmed by the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme which was framed as a result of the decision in Civil Suit No. 18 of 1897 was companyfirmed by the Calcutta High Court

facts.text: The scheme was modified by Calcutta High Court on September 8, 1910.

anchor.surface_text: the matter was taken to the Calcutta High Court, and on September 8, 1910, that Court on the authority of the decision of the Judicial Committee in Prayag Doss v. Tirumala

facts.text: Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 (Bihar I of 1951) received President's assent on February 21, 1951, and came into force on August 15, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950  Bihar I of 1951 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, received the Presidents assent on February 21, 1951, and came into force on August 15. 1951.

facts.text: In August 1952, the President of the Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts asked the respondent to furnish a statement under s. 59 of the Act for Baidyanath temple.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in August 1952 the President of the Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts acting under s. 59 of the Act asked the respondent to furnish a statement in respect of the Baidyanath temple and the. properties appertaining thereto.

facts.text: The respondent refused to furnish the statement, claiming the temple is administered under a scheme by Burdwan District Judge and Calcutta High Court outside Bihar jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent wrote back to say that the administration of the temple and its properties was in the hands of a companymittee companystituted under a scheme made by the District Judge of Burdwan and approved by the Calcutta High Court, and these Courts being outside the jurisdiction of the Bihar Legislature, the Act did number apply to the temple

facts.text: The Board assessed and demanded Rs. 1,684-6-6 as fee from the respondent under s. 70 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Board, however, proceeded to assess and demand payment of Rs. 1,684-6-6 as fee payable by the respondent in respect of the Baidyanath temple to it under s. 70 of the Act.

facts.text: The respondent filed application under Art. 226 in Patna High Court, leading to Misc. Judicial Case No. 181 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then made an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Patna, which application gave rise to Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 181 of 1953.

facts.text: Patna High Court allowed the respondent's application, quashed proceedings by the Board, and issued writ prohibiting further proceedings under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the High Court allowed the application of the respondent, quashed the proceedings taken against him by the Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts, and issued a writ prohibiting the said Board from taking any further proceedings against the respondent under any of the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificate under Art. 132 and filed the present appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bihar, the Bihar State Board of Religious Trusts and its President obtained a certificate under Art. 132 of the Constitution from the High Court and the present appeal has been filed by them in pursuance of that certificate.

facts.text: The Baidyanath temple is a public trust, as admitted and held in earlier litigation including Suit No. 18 of 1897.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal under companysideration in this judgment the admitted position is that the Baidyanath temple is a public trust so it was held in the earlier litigation to which we have already referred and the scheme was formulated on that footing in Suit No. 18 of 1897.

facts.text: Properties of the temple lie mainly in Bihar, with some in Burdwan, Murshidabad and Birbhum in West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: it is admitted that the properties belonging to the temple lie mainly in Bihar though there are some properties in the districts of Burdwan, Murshidabad and Birbhum in the present State of West Bengal.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the Act applies to the Baidyanath temple and set aside the High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Act is good and applies to the Baidyanath temple and the properties a pertaining thereto. The result, therefore, is that the appeal succeeds and is allowed with companyts. The judgment and order of the High Court dated October 9, 1953, are set aside
under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Patna, which application gave rise to Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 181 of 1953. On various grounds stated therein, the respondent
obtained a certificate under Art. 132 of the Constitution from the High Court and the present appeal has been filed by them in pursuance of that certificate. We shall hereinafter refer to them

holdings.text: The Act is not bad on the ground that its several provisions infringe fundamental rights under Art. 14, Art. 19(1)(f), Arts. 25, 26 and 27 of the Constitution, or that it imposes an unauthorised tax.

We have given reasons for our conclusion that the Act is not bad

holdings.text: The Act does not apply to private trusts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed analysis in connected Civil Appeal No. 343 of 1955; temple here is public.

holdings.text: Section 3 of the Act does not suffer from extra-territoriality; applies to religious trusts situate in Bihar with part property there.

anchor.surface_text: First, there is s. 3 which says inter alia that the Act shall apply to all religious trusts, any part of the property of which is situated in-the State of Bihar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Two conditions fulfilled: trust in Bihar, property in Bihar; rejected in Civil Appeal No. 230 of 1955.

holdings.text: The doctrine of comity of jurisdictions has no application; no conflict or clash between authorities.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal under consideration in this judgment the admitted position is that the Baidyanath temple is a public trust so it was held in the earlier litigation to which we have already referred and the scheme was formulated on that footing in Suit No. 18 of 1897.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No possibility of conflict as s.4(5) ends s.92 CPC jurisdiction for Bihar trusts.

holdings.text: Section 4(5) of the Act is valid and s.92 CPC shall not apply to religious trusts in Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section (5) of s. 4 states inter alia that s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, shall not apply to any religious trust

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bihar competent under Concurrent List item 13 (CPC); President's assent under Art.254(2); no extra-territorial effect on outside courts.

holdings.text: Even if Suit No.18 of 1897 pending, no conflict as s.92 CPC jurisdiction ended by the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Even if Suit No. 18 of 1897 is deemed to be still pending... any further action under the scheme... can be taken... only if the jurisdiction under s. 92... is still preserved... If that jurisdiction has come to an end

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction under s.92 ended; obiter as pendency not decided.

holdings.text: Section 28 of the Act has no extra-territorial operation.

anchor.surface_text: Section 28 deals with the general powers and duties of the Board. We have examined these powers and duties in our decision in connected Civil Appeals

holdings.reasoning_summary: Powers for trust fulfillment; examined in connected appeals; no extra-territoriality.

holdings.text: Section 29 of the Act has no extra-territorial operation; committees function under Board superintendence unless superseded.

anchor.surface_text: Section 29 states - 29(1). Where the supervision of a religious trust is vested in any committee or association appointed by the founder or by a competent Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies to Bihar trusts; same logic as s.4(5); no need to cut down scope.

holdings.text: The Act and its provisions do not suffer from extra-territoriality; territorial nexus satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: The doctrine of territorial nexus which arises in this connection has been commented on before us at great length by,-learned counsel for the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislates on trusts situate in Bihar; doctrine applied as in Civil Appeal No. 230 of 1955.

holdings.text: The Act applies to the Baidyanath temple; High Court judgment set aside; appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Act is good and applies to the Baidyanath temple and the properties a pertaining thereto. The result, therefore, is that the appeal succeeds and is allowed with costs. The judgment and order of the High Court dated October 9, 1953, are set aside

holdings.reasoning_summary: No extra-territoriality; temple public trust in Bihar with properties there; scheme under s.92 CPC superseded.

precedents.citation: Shailajananda Dut Jha v. Umeshanunda Dut Jha 1 ... 1 19O5 2 C.L.J. 460

anchor.surface_text: the decision of the High Court is reported in Shailajananda Dut Jha v. Umeshanunda Dut Jha 1 . This scheme was modified in a subsequent litigation in 1909, when one of the members of the committee applied to the District Judge 1 19O5 2 C.L.J. 460. f

precedents.case_name: Shailajananda Dut Jha v Umeshanunda Dut Jha
precedents.cited_proposition: Confirmation of the scheme framed by the District Judge for administration of the Baidyanath temple

precedents.citation: Prayag Doss v. Tirumala 1 ... 1 196 I.L.R. 3o Mad. 138

anchor.surface_text: that Court on the authority of the decision of the Judicial Committee in Prayag Doss v. Tirumala 1 and with the consent of counsel on both sides, directed the insertion of two clauses in the decree by one of these clauses, liberty was reserved to any person interested to apply to the District Court of Burdwan with reference to the carrying out of the directions of the scheme and by the other clause, liberty was reserved to any person interested to apply from time to time to the Calcutta High Court for any modification of the scheme that might appear necessary or convenient. Under these two clauses the members of the committee subsequently applied to the District Judge of Burdwan that certain directions might be given to the high priest the high priest opposed the application on the ground that it was in essence an application for modification of the scheme and could be entertained only by the High Court. The learned District Judge overruled this objection. The matter was again taken to the Calcutta High Court and that Court directed 1 that the committee must prepare ail annual budget of the income and expenditure 2 that provision must be made for quarterly audit and annual inspection of the accounts 3 that provision should be made for joint control of the temple funds after they have been realised 4 that there must be no undue interference on the part of the committee with the high priest in the internal management of the temple and 5 that no one who has any pecuniary interest in the temple properties or is a creditor of the endowment should serve on the committee. The High Court further directed that clauses embodying the aforesaid five directions should be inserted in the scheme. This decision of the High Court is reported in Umeshananda Dutta Jha v. Sir Ravaneswar Prasad Singh 2 . We now come to more recent events which gave rise to Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 181 of 1953 in the 1 196 I.L.R. 3o Mad. 138. 2 1912 17 C.W.N. 871.

precedents.cited_proposition: Authority for directing insertion of clauses reserving liberty to apply for carrying out or modification of the scheme of temple administration

precedents.citation: Umeshananda Dutta Jha v. Sir Ravaneswar Prasad Singh 2 ... 2 1912 17 C.W.N. 871

anchor.surface_text: This decision of the High Court is reported in Umeshananda Dutta Jha v. Sir Ravaneswar Prasad Singh 2 . We now come to more recent events which gave rise to Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 181 of 1953 in the Patna High Court. 2 1912 17 C.W.N. 871.

precedents.case_name: Umeshananda Dutta Jha v Sir Ravaneswar Prasad Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: Directions for insertion of clauses in scheme regarding budget, audit, joint control of funds, non-interference in internal management, and composition of committee

precedents.citation: Mahant Moti Das v. S. P. Sahi, see p. 563, ante

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeals Nos. 225, 226, 228, 229 and 248 of 1955 1 , which fall in the first category, we have considered the questions if the Act is bad on the ground that its several provisions infringe the appellants fundamental rights guaranteed under Art. 14, Art. 19 1 f , and or Arts. 25, 26 and 27 of the Constitution, or on the ground that it imposes an unauthorised tax. We have given reasons for our conclusion that the Act is not bad on any of the aforesaid grounds. These reasons we do not wish to repeat here they govern the present appeal also in so far as the Act is challenged on the self-same grounds. Mahant Moti Das v. S. P. Sahi, see p. 563, ante.

precedents.case_name: Mahant Moti Das v S P Sahi
precedents.cited_proposition: The Bihar Hindu Religious Trusts Act, 1950 does not infringe fundamental rights under Articles 14, 19(1)(f), 25, 26, 27 or impose unauthorised tax
precedents.cited_holding: Act is not bad on grounds of violating fundamental rights or unauthorised taxation

precedents.citation: Mahant Ram Saroop Dasji v. S. P. Sahi, see P. 583, ante

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 343 of 1955 2 , which is in the second category, we have dealt at length with the definition clause of the expression religious trust in the context of other provisions of the Act, and have come to the conclusion that the Act does not apply to private trusts. Mahant Ram Saroop Dasji v. S. P. Sahi, see P. 583, ante.

precedents.case_name: Mahant Ram Saroop Dasji v S P Sahi
precedents.cited_proposition: The Act does not apply to private religious trusts
precedents.cited_holding: Religious trust definition excludes private trusts

precedents.citation: State of Bihar v. Charusila Dasi, see p. 601, ante

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 230 of 1955 3 , which is the third category, we have considered the question if the Act suffers from the vice of extra-territoriality by reason of the provisions in s. 3, which says that the Act shall apply to all religious trusts, whether created before or after the commencement of the Act, any part of the property of which is situate in the State of Bihar. We have held therein that two conditions must be fulfilled for the application of the Act- a the religious trust or institution itself must be in Bihar and b part of its property must be situated in the State of Bihar. State of Bihar v. Charusila Dasi, see p. 601, ante.

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v Charusila Dasi
precedents.cited_proposition: Act applies to religious trusts situate in Bihar with some property in Bihar; no extra-territorial operation
precedents.cited_holding: Two conditions for application: trust in Bihar and part property in Bihar

precedents.citation: State of Bihar v. Charusila Dasi, see p. 601, ante
